channel.title: BBC News - Home
channel.description: The latest stories from the Home section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Kerry: 'We could have shot down jets'
item.description: The US would have been within its rights to shoot down Russian jets that flew close to a warship in the Baltic Sea, Secretary of State John Kerry says.

item.title: Democrats to debate as tensions rise
item.description: Democratic presidential hopefuls Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders will face off in their final debate before the crucial New York primary.

item.title: Butterfly migration mystery solved
item.description: Scientists solve the navigation mystery of one of nature's most famous journeys - the migration of monarch butterflies from Canada to Mexico.

item.title: VIDEO: Chimp rescued from power line
item.description: A chimp that escaped from the Yagiyama Zoological Park in Sendai, Japan, is recovering after falling from a power line.

item.title: VIDEO: Putin answers to public in annual Q&A
item.description: Vladimir Putin answers questions from the public during a four hour live phone-in programme.

item.title: VIDEO: 'Bracing for a tidal wave of migrants'
item.description: Libya has warned that it does not have the resources to control the flow of people heading to Europe. It has accused the EU of failing to deliver on promises of help.

item.title: VIDEO: 'I lost 16 members of my family'
item.description: Asya Hekmat, an Iraqi Kurd migrant, lost 16 members of her family when the boat that took them from Turkey to Greece capsized.

item.title: VIDEO: Mother meets baby 12 days after Caesarean birth
item.description: An orangutan meets her baby after they were separated immediately after birth.

item.title: VIDEO: Daily reality of Ukraine's 'forgotten war'
item.description: As fighting continues in eastern Ukraine between the army and pro-Russian rebels, the BBC's Tom Burridge looks at life on both sides of the frontline.

item.title: Deadly quake rocks southern Japan
item.description: At least nine people have died and more than 250 are injured after a magnitude 6.4 earthquake jolts southern Japan.

item.title: Charles Manson follower may get parole
item.description: Leslie Van Houten, a former follower of Charles Manson, is recommended for parole after spending more than 40 years in prison.

item.title: Hong Kong teen ‘ran Australia drug ring’
item.description: A Hong Kong woman, 19, faces life in prison for allegedly importing crystal meth to Australia via mail.

item.title: Brazil government seeks to block vote
item.description: Brazil's government seeks an injunction at the Supreme Court in an effort to prevent an impeachment vote against President Dilma Rousseff.

item.title: Federal police 'saw Iguala students'
item.description: Mexico's human rights commission says two Mexican federal police officers participated in the disappearance of 43 students in Guerrero state in 2014.

item.title: Mass police raid on German mega-brothel
item.description: Nine hundred police officers take part in a raid on one of Germany's biggest brothels in Berlin, making six arrests over alleged human trafficking and tax fraud.

item.title: Iraq forces 'recapture IS-held Hit'
item.description: Iraqi troops have recaptured the strategically important western town of Hit from Islamic State militants, after weeks of fighting, officials say.

item.title: Sandy Hook lawsuit can move forward
item.description: The families of the Sandy Hook shooting victims win a small legal victory after a judge rules their lawsuit against a gun maker can continue.

item.title: No charges for Trump campaign manager
item.description: A Florida prosecutor will not charge Republican front-runner Donald Trump's campaign manager for alleged battery against a reporter at a campaign event.

item.title: Canada moves to rule out suicide tourism
item.description: A long awaited assisted-suicide bill has been put before Canada's Parliament that protects doctors, but with a proviso that prevents foreigners coming to die.

item.title: Can orcas ever be healthy in captivity?
item.description: Can killer whales ever be healthy in captivity?

item.title: VIDEO: The marble racing craze that's captivated the internet
item.description: Meet the man whose intricate marble racetracks have captivated the internet

item.title: Gay Chinese pledge not to enter into sham marriages
item.description: China's gay community's online pledge

item.title: Quiz of the week's news
item.description: Why didn't Prince George get taken to India by his parents?

item.title: The village losing its livelihood after Kerala temple tragedy
item.description: The village losing its livelihood after Kerala temple tragedy

item.title: Daily reality of Ukraine's 'frozen war'
item.description: Life on the front line in east Ukraine

item.title: Why is America pulling down the projects?
item.description: Why is America pulling down the projects?
